PAST meets PRESENT - full story
Simon Clifford
<td width="73%" class="bodytext"><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Simon studies Sport Health &amp
column2: Leisure and Media at TAS before taking a PGCE in Primary Education. Having honed his teaching skills in a Leeds school, he now uses these and his media acumen in running the governing body for Futebol de Salao. Simon employs a number of ex-TAS students and offers attachments on a regular basis.

column1: Brazalian Soccer, Futebol de Salao

Futebol de Salao is a game which originated in Brazil but which was brought to England by ex-TASC student, Simon Clifford. The game is now thriving throughout the country and has been adopted as a pillar of training for young players by many of the country's top profession.

So impressed, or possibly concerned, was the English Football Association with the way Brazil played at the 1950 World Cup that they set up a technical committee to examine Brazilian training methods. They met just once and decided to take no further action. Eight years later, Brazil won the first of their four World titles. In 1997, football coach, Middlesbrough fan and ex-TASC student Simon Clifford did what the FA should have done and went to see for himself how the Brazilians do it.
Clifford studied their methods, most importantly the unique five-a-side game "
column3: to which most of the great Brazilian players he spoke to attribute their skills. He has since set up a Confederation of Futebol de Salao in England, and the game is beginning to sit up and take notice. What he discovered is now helping, at last, to transform the game in England. Simon has written a book Play the Brazilian Way to explain the training methods through which Brazilian footballers develop their renowned skill and athleticism.

column1: SIMON CLIFFORD, QUOTES FROM HIS 1999 VIDIEO ‘

column2: Brazilian star players now all come from middle class backgrounds. They are players that have learned with a Futsal (small heavy ball) at a soccer school. When Juninio came to coach my young players he was amazed that we taught players using large footballs. Juninio never played 11v11 until he was 15 years old. Rivalino &amp
column3: Zico, truly great players echo the same sentiment. They both found 11v11 easy because they had honed their technical skills playing fast, skilful small-sided football before progressing to a bigger </font><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"></font><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">ball &amp
column4: pitch. This at a later date than the average British kid.&#8221

column1: Katie Crowley

Student Katie Crowley captained the England Basketball team to first place in the British University Games that took place during the Easter break. As well as captaining the winning team, Katie won MVP for the tournament.

Katie represented the England senior womens side in Iceland in May 2003, in preparation for the Commonwealth Games. She started playing basketball age 12 and has played for England in all age groups: U15, U17, U19, U20 and Seniors. In total she has 17 caps for England Seniors.
At club level, Katie plays for Sheffield Hatters Seniors and has represented British Universities and England Universities.
Katie Crowley appeared on the Weakest Link in December.
She was one of several England sporting representatives taking part in the show.
Chantel Adeleye
<td width="73%" class="bodytext"><font face="Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Chantel is in Year 1 of a Joint Honours degree in Sports, Health &amp

Before beginning her course, Chantel successfully secured a Skillset Millennium Award and in February 2004 she was invited to BAFTA in London to collect her Award. Chantel used the funding she received as part of the award to produce, direct and edit a short documentary about the Nail Art Industry. The film is now archived, together with other award-winning media projects, in the Victoria and Albert Museum.

In November 2003, Chantel entered her first figure bodybuilding contest, the South East England NABBA Bodybuilding Competition. A strict diet and hours of training in the gym paid off when Chantel won 1st place in the Novice class, 1st place in the Miss Doncaster class, and 3rd place in the Figure class &#8211
column2: an impressive result for a first timer!

column1: In May 2004 Chantel flew to Canada to start a six week Work Placement with the World National Sports Organisation (WNSO) of Canada. Whilst there she will be helping in the organising and hosting of FAME Canada –
column2: the largest fitness expo in the country.

column1: Sam Evanson
It was also the first half season that I began competing in triathlon, started off as a Sprint distance (750m Swim, 20km Bike, 5km Run) triathlete, at which I posted sub hour times.
I joined the BTA at the start of the following season
column2: this meant that I was able to enter the national race series and accrue points for the national league.

column1: This meant that I had to race over the Olympic distance (1500m Swim, 40km Bike, 10km Run). To start I found this too be a very hard event, but with increasing training &
column2: acclimation to the events, I now find myself posting sub two hours 30 minutes.

column1: My training schedule consists of: four one hour swim sessions per week, five two hour bike sessions per week, three 30 minute to one hour run sets per week, and finally two one hour weight sessions per week. Total training time of 19 hours per week, sometimes three sessions per day.
This is my training schedule of the winter, with the emphasis on base fitness
column2: I will be increasing the workload in the New Year to look more at strength and endurance training for the new season.

column1: Mia Nileskog
Mia is going on to do postgraduate study in Italy.
Sally Piesse
Sally competed in the National Biathlon Championship in Sheffield on 16-17th November 2002 and came third in her age group (19-21 years).
The competition involved 2k run and a 200m swim.
Simon Webb
I have been involved in athletics since I was 12 and it has taken me 11 years to become an England international.
I represented England at the Commonwealth Games in Manchester in the EAD 100m (Elite Athletes with Disabilities), but my preferred event is the 200m.

I have been a member of Richmond and Twickenham Athletics club since the age of 15 and when I came to Trinity and All Saints I needed to find somewhere to train. The college put me in contact with Leeds City Athletics Club, based at South Leeds Stadium. I had been training with the Great Britain squad for a couple of years prior to coming to Leeds but it was the help of my coach Clem Barkley that turned me into a full England international.

column3: All Saints. He is currently playing in the North of England Boys&#8217
column4: Golf Championship and plans to study for a Masters in Health Promotion later this year.
